Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2014 12:39PM NineTwelve wrote: People can be self-absorbed, can't they? I stayed with a friend for several days who smoked nonstop while I was in the room. I even said, "Excuse me, I have cancer? Can you go outside? Or take a nicotine patch?" His solution was to sit next to the window, with all the smoke blowing in towards the room. But my family was well-behaved and thoughtful this year, and for that I'm grateful. Though I agree with you, Mrs. M, that it is great to come here where there is a depth of understanding that is sometimes missing "out there." Congratulations on your decision to stop working. It must be very liberating and a little sad, too. I hope the new chapter is a good one for you.

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2015 01:43PM - edited Apr 14, 2015 01:44PM by NineTwelve Last month I was watching Archer (animated adult comedy series) with my sort-of boyfriend, and the title character gets breast cancer. I asked if we could watch something else. We did. Later, I agreed to try again. I found the episode didn't bother me anymore, and I even laughed at some of the cancer clichés. I'm trying to say, you don't have to watch the show with your SO, or if you do, you two could save it for a future time when it doesn't bother you. Also, it's just a show, and your feelings are (or should be) more important to your SO than any television show could ever be. Give him a chance to prove it, and tell him how it makes you sad. You can and will get over your feelings about the show, but you can and should share your feelings with your partner. That's my take, anyway.

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2015 10:17AM NineTwelve wrote: I agree with the above. I had a lot of that kind of evasion and pussyfooting around in the beginning of my diagnosis. I switched oncologists to someone (at the same office) who would answer my questions without trying to sugarcoat or peptalk me. If you are having trust issues with your doctor, they will not resolve on their own. Getting a new one is best, if you can. If not, maybe a frank talk with the one you have. You are a medical professional yourself, and that must give you some insight into the medical world and the way things are done. You have to put aside your fear to do that, though. It helps to take some kind of action. Exercise, and read all about your kind of cancer. Start researching ways to improve your overall health. If you can stand needles, acupuncture is a good way to get rid of anxiety, insomnia, aches and pains and other things that interfere with well-being and calm. Find your most supportive friend and talk about your worries. And then give that friend a best-case scenario, to cheer you both up. You don't know what your future will be. It may not be as bad as you fear. It will not be all bad. Life is still wonderful, even when it is hard. Please keep posting and let us know how you're doing.

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2014 11:16AM - edited Nov 30, 2014 11:17AM by NineTwelve Hi, poniesandpuppies. I'm pretty new here, but I was diagnosed with lung mets from the start. It's very scary and surreal, and I blanked out a lot at first. Your oncologist will help you decide on a treatment plan. Everyone's different and (as my doctor says "Not every cancer has read the rule book") so it's hard to say what's next for you, or even what's common. A lot depends on what kind of treatments you've had already and what your hormone receptor status is. If those spots on your lung are cancer from your original disease, then you have metastatic breast cancer. You don't get to be fixed now, but you could be symptom-free for a long time, if your treatments are effective. The closest we get to cured in the MBC world is something called NED, No Evidence of Disease, which does happen and which we all hope for, for ourselves and everyone else with this illness. Don't be frightened by the statistics, they don't tell the whole story, they don't necessarily reflect current treatments, and they group lots of different kinds of cancers together, all of which have differing prognoses. Someone will be along with more experience than I have with your situation (recurrence vs new dx) and will have more helpful advice. I just want to say, you are not alone and you can do this.

Not that I wish that on you instead. But in answer to your question, what you are going through is not like my lung mets experience. And I hope the shortness of breath goes away soon.

(I should mention the fluid is in the chest cavity around my right lung only, the left lung looks clear.) I just started Tamoxifen and Zoladex therapy on October 3rd. I'll have my second treatment on Halloween. For those who responded to treatments, did the fluid stop accumulating? Or did you have to get a surgery to make it stop? I would have to say it's my scariest symptom.

Mrs. M - Shortness of breath is a big symptom for lung mets. If you find yourself breathless doing things that used to be no problem, coughing at the end of every laugh, if you have a wheeze or a rattle when you breathe... I had those symptoms, from fluid around my lungs, caused by the cancer on the pleura (lining) of my right lung. The fluid was found by x-ray, accidentally, really. Cancer was confirmed by PET scan. ponies - come back and tell us how you're doing, and what they give you to fight with. You got this!

Posts.Content: May 15, 2015 11:33PM - edited May 15, 2015 11:38PM by NineTwelve I hope you have emailed your oncologist by now, kt. Even if the fluid is just a nuisance and not a threat to your ability to get enough oxygen, you are concerned, and you owe it to yourself to get a medical professional's opinion. I understand the temptation to just wait until your next appointment. It's probably okay to do that. I lived with coughing and shortness of breath for quite some time (months?), thinking I had some kind of allergy or something. The fluid was found accidentally, in the beginning of my diagnostic adventures, after a chest x-ray for something else. The doctor looking at the x-ray told me one lung was half submerged in fluid. He explained the thoracentesis procedure and said I could get one if my breathing got worse. It was when I found myself stopping to catch my breath after walking one or two blocks (flat, no hills) that I decided I needed to get drained. I called my regular doctor and she believed me on the spot (no need to see her or any other doc first), and she hung up the phone and put in my referral me for the thoracentesis. (My insurance requires patients to go through one primary care doc, who has to refer us to all specialists.) Thoracentesis is a really easy outpatient procedure. It takes about twenty minutes. They looked at my x-ray, numbed my back, and stuck a metal tube between my ribs and syphoned off two liters of fluid. It's not pleasant, but it was not terribly painful, and I felt better later that same day. This was at the beginning of my treatment. The Tamoxifen started working right away to shrink my tumors and so far, I haven't had any more shortness of breath, cough, or rattle when I breathe.

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2014 10:44AM NineTwelve wrote: Yes, great topic. I have a low-status office job and live alone, and have always thought my life lacked a sense of community or meaning. Mrs. M has a good point, though: if I am living in the moment doing what I love, then does it matter if it's useful or even memorable? It only matters to me, I guess. I have three unfinished novels in my laptop. Yesterday I had a bad day with no energy and more pain than usual. I wondered if I would have enough time or presence of mind to finish anything. What was the point in trying? Today I realize I didn't take a walk or do any exercise yesterday, or talk to anyone, so that might be why I felt so low. I plan to do better today. raro, I think your cat tree project sounds like a real accomplishment, and it's also a physical reminder of the time your family spent together making it. Just don't beat yourself up about how you spend your time. Even high achievers in good health feel down sometimes, with less excuse than we have.

Lug all that stuff to work (on my bicycle) and take a break every hour so I can drink fresh juice? And another four breaks for the coffee enemas... Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2014 10:25AM - edited Nov 19, 2014 10:26AM by NineTwelve I used to work in magazine publishing. The goal is to have 50-75 percent advertising per issue. Sales staff sell ad space based on the subject and placement of the article. I'm guessing few advertisers want their product nestled in with talk of death and dying. A friend once pointed out that basically all women's magazines are the same every month. The household mags have a big picture of food, with a decadent desserts article and a diet article. The younger women's mags all have something about a celebrity, and a "what he likes in bed" article. I don't buy magazines anymore. Back on topic though: I agree with the original post that there is very little media attention on metastatic cancer, and that when earlier stage cancers are discussed, the advanced stages are barely, if at all, even mentioned.

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2017 11:10PM NineTwelve wrote: Hi, Ty I'm on that protocol. I was so tired in the beginning. Like - I would wait an extra hour to get up to pee because I was so tired and didn't want to walk across a room to get to the bathroom. It got so much better when my oncologist lowered my dose of Ibrance from 125 to 100 mg. Also, I see an acupuncturist - once a week in the beginning, then once every other week, now once a month. And I take at least a 20 minute walk every day. Even when I'm tired, because I know the fatigue is worse if I don't do any walking or stretching (or dancing). I also take something to help me fall asleep at night, because insomnia can make me very tired. (I'm lucky enough to live in a state were medical marijuana is legal). And I asked for help and some accommodations at work. They moved me closer to the area of my main task, and assigned a person to help out when things get too busy. Finally, I would add that before my treatment started working, I had fluid around my lung which meant I would get short of breath, and that caused some fatigue as well. I don't take vitamins. I've seen articles that suggest they may not be helpful for us, and I hate taking pills anyway. To sum up: it's pretty normal to feel extra tired after beginning treatment. After it starts working, you might find yourself perking up! I hope so. Either way, come back and let us know how you do.

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2019 07:32AM NineTwelve wrote: I know my culture is in general and almost complete denial of mortality. We are mortals who have limited time. So it bothers me when I have to waste any time doing the song and dance about how I'm sick but my illness is being managed by meds until they stop working. I'm guilty of the old "but we could all get hit by busses and be dead just like that" (Send in the bus, there has to be bus...Well, maybe next year...) It bothers me that i have to minimize my illness in order for everyone to be comfortable. It bothers me, but I do it, because we just don't have the skills in my immediate family/social circle/work environment to handle life and death issues. We forgot the vocabulary our ancestors created around the constant cycles of birth and death. We have forgotten how to be sympathetic without making presumptions. We want to be kind and caring, but instead we come out with cliches that aren't even true, and certainly don't help, except maybe minimally as we convey that we care, even if we can't say the right thing. I want to apologize to anyone I ever slighted by minimizing their fears or pain. I'm sorry, I was trying to be helpful. On a more concrete and more easily remedied level, it really bothers me that the radiologists' office that does my scans can't stop themselves every time from treatment-shaming me. They all insist I should get a mastectomy NOW, even though that is not standard protocol anymore. It's not their job to volunteer treatment advice, why do they keep doing it? Oh, yes, they're trying to help. This is why we need to explore the myths and misconceptions. In some cases, those misconceptions can harm us or prevent us from getting the best care there is for our disease.
Posts.Title: Myths/Misconceptions about MBC- please share with us! Moderators Sparkles2_2

Posts.Title: Bummer kebab exbrnxgrl

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2015 09:55AM - edited Nov 23, 2015 09:56AM by NineTwelve The hardest part for me is: everything else. In the last month, my brother and I discovered our parents, 86 and 91, can't take care of each other anymore. They need to be moved from another state to live in the same town as us. My brother is teetering on the brink of divorce (and I love my SIL dearly). The California tax board garnished my brother's bank account for something that happened (or didn't happen - he can't prove it, because it was so long ago) in 2001. My disabled, mentally ill sister is getting evicted (and we found out her caretaker, to whom she is very attached, has some kind of criminal record, thus making it very difficult for them to find other low-income housing - as if it weren't already hard enough.) So, now we are looking at moving three, maybe four, adult dependents during the winter holidays. I saw a therapist last week, and I had to tell her, "I have a terminal illness, but that is the least of my worries." It's just so hard. Sometimes I want to give up.

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2015 08:57AM NineTwelve wrote: Thank you artistatheart and suersis for the kind remarks. The therapist gave me some helpful advice, along the lines of "try to have more positive thoughts." She phrased it better, but ever since then, I've been examining how I always assume the worst, trying to avoid disappointment. Well, you can't avoid disappointment in this life, whether you mentally prepare for it or not. And worry is even more exhausting than disappointment, so it's not a good trade! All you who worry about your loved ones after you're gone: no one is ever alone. There is always kindness. There is enough love. My heart is welling even now as I think of the support and encouragement I have received here from people who don't know me, but who care about me nonetheless. You are all angels. Thank you.

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2015 12:25PM NineTwelve wrote: I'm going to a cancer center. It was scary to walk in there for the first time and see bald people with respirators, but now I'm comforted by the fact that this is what they do: they take care of people with the same illness I have, and they know what they're doing. I have seen several doctors in only a few short months. In the beginning I was numb and just went along like a sheep. But I did switch doctors (medical oncologist) because the first one seemed totally burnt out and stressed. And at one point, when I got a bad feeling about a procedure, I spoke up to my new M.O. who reassured me there were other options that would work just as well. I will say, you will have more interactions with your M.O. than your surgeon, so make sure you get one you like and trust. Keeping my fingers crossed that you get encouraging news at your first appointment. Please come back and give us an update, if you feel up to it. There are a lot of caring and knowledgeable people on this board.

Posts.Content: May 18, 2016 08:10PM NineTwelve wrote: Hi everyone. I haven't posted in a while, because my family situation blew up, in a big way. Currently my mom is in hospice, after her stroke. My dad, brother, and I go visit her daily, though she can't speak or swallow. It's horrible to watch, but it's what she wanted. She insisted on the feeding tube. She really wants to keep going. I don't understand it, but it is her will. I had a new PET scan yesterday and I will get the results on Friday. I really feel like my cancer is back, and I can't shake the feeling. Just needed to share that, because my cancer is not a priority for my folks right now; they all have their own shit to deal with. Thanks, and pardon my French.
Posts.Title: Having a scan? Waiting on results? The waiting room is open! exbrnxgrl gramen

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2016 01:08PM - edited Jul 20, 2016 01:14PM by NineTwelve May 18, 2016 08:10PM NineTwelve wrote: Hi everyone. I haven't posted in a while, because my family situation blew up, in a big way. Currently my mom is in hospice, after her stroke. My dad, brother, and I go visit her daily, though she can't speak or swallow. It's horrible to watch, but it's what she wanted. She insisted on the feeding tube. She really wants to keep going. I don't understand it, but it is her will. I had a new PET scan yesterday and I will get the results on Friday. I really feel like my cancer is back, and I can't shake the feeling. Hello, again. I posted the above back in May when I had my PET scan. My oncologist wasn't worried when we got the results, showing activity in the main tumor sites (right breast and armpit), but he referred me for a new mammogram and sonogram. With everything going on in my family, and no one to remind me, I forgot about the mammo. Two months later, my oncologist's nurse called me to say where were those mammogram results? I had to say, no one called me to schedule, and I just forgot about it. I thought the PET scan showed everything still stable... Fast forward to this morning... Today was my mammogram and sonogram. The radiologist said it looks like there is a tumor on the chest wall, under the primary tumor, which is why it wasn't seen on the PET. I don't know what to do now. I guess my oncologist will call me? what happens now?
Posts.Title: Having a scan? Waiting on results? The waiting room is open! exbrnxgrl gramen

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2016 04:23PM NineTwelve wrote: Hi zarovka, thank you for the words of support. I've been spending hours poring over the Ibrance and Faslodex (and the Ibrance & Faslodex) threads. I feel better today. (Fuck you, Cancer, I'm not dead yet.) I have the book you mentioned. I'm also getting some help from the book Breast Cancer: 50 Essential Things to Do. Something that really resonates, as I deal with my helpless dysfunctional parents, is the foreword, written by Dr. Christine Northrop. She describes the Adverse Childhood Experience (ACE) study, that concluded unmet childhood needs set the stage for future illnesses. She goes on to quote Lewis Thomas, "I have come to believe that cancer is the physical metaphor for the extreme need to grow." Maybe that's a topic for a separate thread - because things can get pretty heated when we start talking about cancer as a metaphor (journey, war, wake-up call, etc). So I won't go there. It means different things to us at different times, I guess. One thing that's not controversial: without this forum I would be so lost. Thank you all, again. I can never say that enough times.
Posts.Title: Having a scan? Waiting on results? The waiting room is open! exbrnxgrl gramen

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2016 06:16PM NineTwelve wrote: Thanks, artistatheart. I just got off the phone with my oncologist. Progression. We are switching to Ibrance (which he calls "Imbrance") and Faslodex. Still no question of surgery; he ruled that out. It's just as well, though, because I have no one to help me through the recovery. And I need my work, because it keeps me from spinning those worry wheels. It keeps me distracted. Helps me feel like I'm valued. I am more calm now, though the tears are falling. I am numb. Funny how you don't just get the bad news once, with this disease. You get to do it over and over. Fun times.
Posts.Title: Having a scan? Waiting on results? The waiting room is open! exbrnxgrl gramen

Sounds like you're making the most of your life right now, even with all the worry and - wow - a scan every six weeks! I guess I could get used to that, but it blows my mind. The courage I see here really inspires me. Yes, now is the time for treatment to kick that cancer to the curb!

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2019 09:39AM NineTwelve wrote: I lost 15 pounds pretty easily when I gave up dairy four years ago, out of concern over estrogen and growth hormones feeding the cancer. If you think about it, milk was designed to take a 90 pound newborn calf to a 500 pound calf in three to four months. It was made for weight gain! And it has way more estrogen when it comes from a cow in its last stages of pregnancy, as opposed to from a cow which has given birth and is lactating to feed its young. This Harvard study is interesting: https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2014/04/milk-hormones-cancer-pregnant-cows-estrogen/

Posts.Title: Trying to find a common cause. Please help! sunny8 msphil

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2015 10:25AM NineTwelve wrote: Hi, Bobcat (beautiful animals, aren't they?) I was very sad to learn that surgery was no longer recommended for me after they finally got all the tests in and staged me at IV. At first. Then I was put on Tamoxifen and it shrank all my tumors within a few months, with very minimal side effects. I am currently stable, with tumor markers in the normal range. I live like someone who isn't sick. It's amazing and wonderful. If I had had the mastectomy, I would still be dealing with pain, scars, and possible complications from it (not to scare you, but it is a major procedure.) Since your cancer is already metastasized, I wonder if you might give the anti-hormonals a chance to work? The horse is out of the barn, so to speak. At any rate, this is something worth discussing with your medical oncologist. The thing is, for us, going aggressive doesn't guarantee anything except an aggressive treatment. The cancer cells are still in our blood.
Posts.Title: masectomy for stage iv breast cancer Bobcat86 Zillsnot4me

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2015 02:13PM NineTwelve wrote: I am really glad somebody bumped this thread up. I agree with everything here, and it is so important to reflect on this from time to time, so we can use our time to best effect, but not dwell (so we don't give ourselves needless mental suffering). This is the post that really got to me today: Feb 19, 2013 02:26PM JillThut wrote: I think most of us feel that way...until we don't anymore. I got a good three years of feeling that way. Enjoy it. But don't put off anything important.
Posts.Title: I don't feel sick cheryl1946 NineTwelve

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2015 04:41PM NineTwelve wrote: I wish the diagnostic process had been more organized, and more streamlined. I was tired, sick and terrified, but I still had to shuttle back and forth to different providers at four different clinics, did tests I now think of as redundant or inadequate, and talk to people who didn't have the whole picture, describing different approaches that were later dropped when the diagnosis finally came in. Each diagnostician had a different focus and it wasn't until the very end that I met my MO, who was the one that finally pulled everything together and had the bigger picture. I was seriously stressed by the time they finally figured me out. Treatment (so far) has been calm and orderly in comparison. I also scorn all the things on leggo's list. Well said, leggo - I think you covered most of the bases. Except insurance crap. I hate those bastards, too. (And I have good coverage.)

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2017 02:04PM NineTwelve wrote: Hell yes. If I ASK you what should I wear, you can tell me. If I forgot to zip my pants, you can let me know. If I'm missing a shoe, you might want to mention it. Otherwise, I'll just do me, and you do you. I might have much bigger things to worry about than looking lopsided or boyish. I might be focused on saving the world, or just my own life. Just saying, I really regret all the time I have spent reading fashion magazines and worrying about not being attractive enough. I wish I had spent that time studying politics or finance. I could have done so many more things with my life!
